00020 /** \file
00021  \brief serial stuff
00022  */
00023 
00024 #ifndef __OBDSERIAL_H
00025 #define __OBDSERIAL_H
00026 
00027 #include "obdconvertfunctions.h"
00028 
00029 /// This is returned from getobdvalue
00030 enum obd_serial_status {
00031     OBD_SUCCESS, ///< Successfully found value
00032     OBD_NO_DATA, ///< Got a NO DATA message
00033     OBD_UNPARSABLE, ///< Couldn't parse OBD return message
00034     OBD_INVALID_RESPONSE, ///< Invalid response
00035     OBD_INVALID_MODE, ///< Invalid mode
00036     OBD_UNABLE_TO_CONNECT, ///< Device reported UNABLE TO CONNECT
00037     OBD_ERROR ///< Some other error
00038 };
00039 
00040 /// The timeout for serial reads in general, measured in usec
00041 #define OBDCOMM_TIMEOUT 10000000l
00042 
00043 /// Open the serial port and set appropriate options
00044 /**
00045  \param portfilename path and filename of the serial port
00046  \param baudrate -1 for "don't touch", 0 for "guess", >0 for the passed number
00047  \param baudrate_target -1 for "don't touch", 0 for "guess", >0 for the passed number
00048  \return fd on success or -1 on error
00049  */
00050 int openserial(const char *portfilename, long baudrate, long baudrate_target);
00051 
00052 /// Close the serialport
00053 void closeserial(int fd);
00054 
00055 /// Modify the baudrate of the passed serial port
00056 /**
00057  \param baurdate attempt to set to this value. -1 makes no changes
00058  \param fd the opened serial port to try it on
00059  \return 0 on success, or -1 on failure
00060  */
00061 int modifybaud(int fd, long baudrate);
00062 
00063 /// Write to this log
00064 int startseriallog(const char *logname);
00065 
00066 /// Close the log
00067 void closeseriallog();
00068 
00069 /// Get the currently set error codes.
00070 enum obd_serial_status getobderrorcodes(int fd,
00071         unsigned int *retvals, unsigned int retvals_size, int *numbytes_returned);
00072 
00073 /// Get an OBD value
00074 /** This sends "01 cmd-in-hex" to the OBD device.
00075  It then grabs all the data returned and does its best to put it into the return value
00076  \param fd the serial port opened with openserial
00077  \param cmd the obd service command
00078  \param ret the return value
00079  \param numbytes the number of bytes we expect in the response [optimisation]. Set to zero for safe-nothing-can-go-wrong
00080  \param conv the convert function to get from A,B,C,D to a float
00081  \return something from the obd_serial_status enum 
00082  */
00083 enum obd_serial_status getobdvalue(int fd, unsigned int cmd, float *ret, int numbytes, OBDConvFunc conv);
00084 
00085 /// Get the raw bits returned from an OBD command
00086 /** This returns some unsigned integers. Each contains eight bits
00087     in its low byte and zeros in the rest
00088  \param fd the serial port opened with openserial
00089  \param cmd the obd service command
00090  \param numbytes_expected the number of bytes we expect in the response [optimisation]. Set to zero for safe-nothing-can-go-wrong
00091  \param retvals_size number of retvals allocated in the retvals array
00092  \param retvals array of retvals_size items to stuff with retvalues
00093  \param numbytes_returned tells you how many of retvals were filled.
00094  \return something from the obd_serial_status enum
00095 */
00096 enum obd_serial_status getobdbytes(int fd, unsigned int mode, unsigned int cmd, int numbytes_expected,
00097         unsigned int *retvals, unsigned int retvals_size, int *numbytes_returned, int quiet);
00098 
00099 /// Get the number of errors codes the car claims to currently have
00100 int getnumobderrors(int fd);
00101 
00102 #endif // __OBDSERIAL_H
